utterance: "I say, Mr. Butts, kin I git the loan uv one uv your hosses un your leetle wagon to fetch the doctor? My ole woman's purty bad; been sick ever sence the sun was 'n 'our high, un we can't git nothin' to do no good."
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "What seems to be the matter?"
speaker: Lysander Butts

utterance: "Blamed 'f I know jest what it is. I suspicion it 's the dyspepsy. Whatever 't is, she don't think she kin git through till mornin' 'thout I git a doctor."
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "Well, I doan know. The sorrel 's lame; un I don't like to let the bay colt go noways, he 's sech a sperrited critter."
speaker: Lysander Butts

utterance: "Looky h-yer, Mr. McCord, you don't want no doctor nohow. You jest take along with you a bottle of my new medicine, 't I call the 'Scatter Misery.' It's made out-uh roots an' yarbs, an' it 's the best thing I know fer mos' every kind of complaint. It's good insides an' outsides. You rub the Scatter Misery onto the outsides un give her a swaller now un then insides. It'll fetch 'er 'roun' in an hour or two."
speaker: Mrs. Butts

utterance: "I'm much obleeged, Mrs. Butts, but my ole woman tole me ez I wuz n't to come back 'thout a doctor; un ef you hain't got no critter you kin len' me, I mus' be a-gittin' 'long down to Albaugh's mighty quick. That's a powerful ways off, though. I wish I'd gone there straight un not come over h-yer."
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "Aw, well, Bob, I don't like to disobleege a neighbor. You kin have the bay colt; but you must drive slow, Bob. He's a young thing un the fidgetiest critter."
speaker: Lysander Butts

utterance: "Tom!"
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "In the dungeon."
speaker: Tom Grayson

utterance: "Dern the luck!"
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "What's the matter, Bob?"
speaker: Tom Grayson

utterance: "We must git a cole-chisel,"
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "Whach yeh go'n' to do?"
speaker: Zeke Tucker

utterance: "Come on, quick!"
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "Heap uh use uh lockin' the door,"
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "Blow up the belluses there un see ef you kin make a light."
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "We'll have to gin up the c'nundrum, Did n' you say as you 'lowed the sher'f was expectin' Jake?"
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "Yes, Jake's got a kind-uv a secret urrangement weth Plunkett's brother-in-law. Jake's to make the derndest kind uv a row, un the sher'f's to talk about dyin' 'n 'is tracks un all that, you know. That's some weeks ago 't the sher'f's brother-in-law fixed all that up, un Jake, he tole us they would n' be no danger."
speaker: Zeke Tucker

utterance: "Turn your coat wrong sides out, Now tie your han'kercher acrost yer face, so 's to kiver all below yer eyes."
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "Whach yeh go'n' to do?"
speaker: Zeke Tucker

utterance: "What 'll we do fer pistols?"
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "There's your pistol, Zeke. Put it jam up agin Plunkett's head un tell him to hole still ur die. We've got to play Jake Hogan onto 'im un git the keys. Th' ain't nary nuther way."
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "We must n't wait fer him to open, he'll see how few we air, Prize away on this yer."
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "Don't kill me, boys,"
speaker: Sheriff Plunkett

utterance: "Say one word un you're a dead man, We won't have no tricks; d' yeh h'yer?"
speaker: Zeke Tucker

utterance: "They's mor' 'n forty uv us, un we want them air keys right straight."
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "If I had half a chance I'd ruther die than give 'em up, but there they air, at the head of my bed"
speaker: Sheriff Plunkett

utterance: "Not a word! We won't hurt you, Mrs. Plunkett, ef you keep still; but ef you make a noise while we 're gone, the boys outside might shoot."
speaker: Bob McCord

speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "What's the matter?"

utterance: "Jake Hogan 'll be h-yer in less 'n no time"

utterance: "fer fear some-body might git in while we're away,"
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "What am I goin' to do weth you, Tom? I wonder 'f you had n' better light out?"
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "Not without Abra'm says so,"
speaker: Tom Grayson

utterance: "Looky h-yer, Tom; when I got the keys from the sher'f, I brought them all along. They 's the big key to the jail, un the key to the dungeon. Now, h-yer, I've got two more. It seems like as ef one uv 'em had orter onlock the east room of the jail, un liker 'n not t' other's the court-house key. S'pose 'n I put you in there; they'll never look there in the worl."
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: "I s'pose so, if you think it's safe. If Abra'm thinks I'd better not clear out, I'll be where I'm wanted in the morning, and they can't say I have run off,"
speaker: Tom Grayson

speaker: Jake Hogan

speaker: Sheriff Plunkett

utterance: "Wha' choo talkin'? We hain't on'y jest got yer."
speaker: Jake Hogan

utterance: "Only just got here? Only just come? Then there's another crowd that must 'a' done the business ahead of you. I guess they 've hung Tom and gone before this."
speaker: Sheriff Plunkett

utterance: "Looky h-yer now, we don't want no more uv your tricks. We're the on'y party out to-night, sartin shore, un we 're boun' to have them air keys ur die, You might 's well gin 'em up fust as last, Hank Plunkett, un save yourself trouble."
speaker: Jake Hogan

utterance: "Well, if you want 'em, you'll have to look 'em up, I have n't got 'em, and I 'll be hanged if I know who has. I was knocked down and nearly killed by a whole lot of men. Kill me, if you 've got a mind to, but you won't find the keys in this house. So there now."
speaker: Sheriff Plunkett

utterance: "Come on, boys; we'll s'arch the jail. Un ef we 've been fooled weth, Hank Plunkett 'll have to pay fer it."
speaker: Jake Hogan

utterance: "Looky h-yer, this ain't no kind uv a place fer women folks. You go 'way."
speaker: Jake Hogan

utterance: "No, I won't go away. I'm Tom's sister and I won't leave him. You must n't shoot him. He did n't kill George Lockwood."

utterance: "You mus' go 'way, ur you 'll git shot yer own self,"
speaker: Jake Hogan

utterance: "Well, shoot me d' you think I care? I'd rather die with Tom. I know your voice, Jake Hogan; and if you kill Tom you'll be a murderer, for he is n't."
speaker: Barbara

utterance: "Take her away, boys,"
speaker: Jake Hogan

utterance: "Down weth that ar door!"
speaker: Jake Hogan

Thunder! Who could
they be? The shuruff says they wuz more 'n forty on 'em ;
so they could n't be rescuers. They hain't ten men in the
wide worl' 'at thinks Tom's innercent. Like 's not it's a
lot uv fellers f'um the south-east of the k-younty, down
towards Hardscrabble, whar Lockwood had some kin.
They 've hung him summers. Let's ride 'roun' un see ef
we kin fin' any traces. Un ef Hank Plunkett has played a
trick, we'll git squar' some day, ur my name hain't Hogan.
speaker: Jake Hogan

utterance:
W'y, Barbara! for goodness' sake, what brought you

utterance:
O Mr. Mason! I'm afraid Tom's dead. I ran after
Jake Hogan and his men when I heard them pass, and
begged Jake to let Tom off. They tried to drive me away,
but I staid; and when they got into jail, Tom was n't
there. Jake said that the sheriff said he had been taken
away and lynched by more than forty men.
Oh, if they
have killed the poor boy!
speaker: Barbara

utterance: Maybe it is n't so bad.
speaker: Hiram Mason

utterance: Don't cry any more, Barbara!
speaker: Hiram Mason

utterance:
I should n't wonder if Bob

speaker: Hiram Mason

utterance: But we left him at home to-night.
speaker: Barbara

utterance: O my poor Tom!
speaker: Barbara

utterance:
That's Butts's wagon, and that 's his bay colt, I do

anything to do with this wicked business.
speaker: Barbara

utterance: Stay here a moment, Barbara.
speaker: Hiram Mason

utterance:
It's all right, Mr. Mason. Tom 's safe

speaker: Bob McCord

utterance: Come and tell Barbara.
speaker: Hiram Mason

utterance: Where is Tom?

utterance:
Oh! I'm a-playin' Abe Lincoln. The fewer that knows, the better it 'll be. Tom says he
won't light out, unless Abra'm says to. Speak'n' of Abe
Lincoln, I don't want to be seed weth him to-
night. You go back, Mr. Mason, un tell Abe 't Tom 's safe.
Ef he thinks Tom's chances is better to stan' trial, w'y, he'll
find 'im in the court-house to-morry when the court wants

Tom hain't got no chance afore a jury, let 'im jest wink one

Ioway country. You go 'n' let Abe know, un I'll see
Barb'ry safe home-she won't gimme the mitten to-night,
I 'low.
speaker: Bob McCord

utterance:
Tom does n't want to be an outlaw. I don't believe he could escape; and if he
